raw_text:
Hotspot users gain free net calls
 
 People using wireless net hotspots will soon be able to make free phone calls as well as surf the net.
 
 Wireless provider Broadreach and net telephony firm Skype are rolling out a service at 350 hotspots around the UK this week. Users will need a Skype account - downloadable for free - and they will then be able to make net calls via wi-fi without paying for net access. Skype allows people to make free PC-based calls to other Skype users.
 
 Users of the system can also make calls to landlines and mobiles for a fee. The system is gaining in popularity and now has 28 million users around the world. Its paid service - dubbed Skype Out - has so far attracted 940,000 users. It plans to add more paid services with forthcoming launches of video conferencing, voice mail and Skype In, a service which would allow users to receive phone calls from landlines and mobiles. London-based software developer Connectotel has unveiled software that will expand the SMS functions of Skype, allowing users to send text messages to mobile phones from the service. Broadreach Networks has around two million users and hotspots in places such as Virgin Megastores, the Travelodge chain of hotels and all London's major rail terminals. The company is due to launch wi-fi on Virgin Trains later in the year. "Skype's success at spreading the world about internet telephony is well-known and we are delighted to be offering free access to Skype users in our hotspots," commented Broadreach chief executive Magnus McEwen-King.
llama3.2:1b: People using wireless hotspots will gain free net calls, surf the web, and make phone calls via wi-fi without paying for internet access. A service called Skype Out allows users to make PC-based calls to other Skype users for free, with 28 million users worldwide. The company plans to add more paid services, including video conferencing and voice mail.
llama3.2:3b: Wireless provider Broadreach and net telephony firm Skype are launching a service allowing Hotspot users to make free Wi-Fi phone calls, requiring a Skype account. Users can also make paid calls to landlines and mobiles. The system has gained 28 million users worldwide and plans to add services such as video conferencing and voice mail.
gemma2:2b:
Hotspot users will be able to make free phone calls via Skype, with a trial starting this week.  Users need a Skype account, which is free to download. Calls can be made to other Skype users for free and to landlines and mobiles for a fee. 
The system has gained popularity and 28 million users worldwide. It offers paid services like Skype Out and plans for video conferencing, voice mail and Skype In soon.  Connectotel has also developed software that expands SMS functions within the service.   Broadreach Networks, which owns many of these hotspots (like Virgin Megastores and London's major rail terminals), is launching Wi-Fi on Virgin Trains later in the year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Hotspot users can make free net calls and browse the web with Skype. Users have to download a Skype account. They can make phone calls via WiFi, which is not free but cheaper than on landlines or mobiles. Skype Out service is available in 28 million locations around the world now. Additional paid services will be introduced in the future. The company provides software that allows users to send SMS messages from their phones using Skype.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Wireless provider Broadreach and net telephony firm Skype are launching a service allowing people using wireless hotspots to make free phone calls and surf the web without paying for internet access. Users need a Skype account, which is available for free download. Calls can also be made to landlines and mobiles at a cost. The system has grown to 28 million users worldwide and plans future services including video conferencing and voice mail. Broadreach currently has two million hotspots in place across the UK.
qwen2.5:3b: Hotspot users will soon be able to make free phone calls via Wi-Fi, as Wireless provider Broadreach partners with net telephony firm Skype for a service at 350 UK hotspots. Users need a Skype account and can call other Skype users for free; they also pay for calls to landlines and mobiles. The service has 28 million users worldwide, with paid services like Skype Out attracting 940,000 users. Connectotel's software will expand SMS capabilities. Broadreach operates in various locations including Virgin Megastores, hotels, and London's rail terminals. CEO Magnus McEwen-King praised the collaboration’s success in spreading internet telephony.

smollm:1.7b: The text summary should preserve key ideas, details, and relationships between them. The main idea of the text is that people will soon have the ability to make free phone calls using wireless net hotspots. This service is being offered by two companies: Broadreach Networks and Skype. The service allows users to make free calls to other users on Skype, but also offers paid services with additional features.

Broadreach and Skype are rolling out a service with 350 hotspots in the UK this week, offering wi-fi access while also providing a paid service called Skype Out, which is expected to expand into video conferencing, voice mail, and SMS functionality. Skype's success in spreading internet telephony is well-known, and they're making free access available to their users using these hotspots. The company has a large user base across various locations including Virgin Megastores, the Travelodge chain of hotels, London's major rail terminals, and expects to launch wi-fi on Virgin Trains by the end of the year.

Skype's 28 million users worldwide are increasingly popular, with paid service Skype Out gaining 940,000 users. Connectotele has unveiled software to expand SMs functions of Skype, allowing users to send text messages from the app. The company is launching wi-fi on Virgin Train's later in the year. Broadreach Networks with over two million users and hotspot locations in London's main rail terminals is set to offer free net calls for its users in Skype's wireless hotspots.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Broadreach, a UK wireless provider, and Skype, a net telephony firm, are collaborating to offer free net calls via 350 UK hotspots starting this week. For calls to landlines and mobiles, users pay a fee through Skype Out, which has 940,000 subscribers globally. Broadreach Networks, with approximately two million users and hotspots at Virgin Megastores, Travelodge, and major London rail terminals, plans to introduce wi-fi on Virgin Trains later this year. chatgpt-4o-latest: Hotspot users in the UK will soon be able to make free internet calls via Wi-Fi, thanks to a partnership between wireless provider Broadreach and net telephony firm Skype. The service, available at 350 hotspots, requires a free Skype account and allows users to make free PC-based calls to other Skype users without paying for internet access. Users can also call landlines and mobiles for a fee through Skype Out, which has 940,000 users. Skype plans to introduce additional paid services, including video conferencing, voicemail, and Skype In, which enables receiving calls from landlines and mobiles. Connectotel has developed software to expand Skype’s SMS functions, allowing text messaging to mobile phones. Broadreach, with two million users and hotspots in locations like Virgin Megastores and major rail terminals, plans to launch Wi-Fi on Virgin Trains later this year. Broadreach CEO Magnus McEwen-King expressed enthusiasm for offering free Skype access at their hotspots.
